title: 109_s2475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006". It establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. Voting and nonvoting members are included in the Commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community includes 23 members appointed by various leaders, with each leader appointing 1 nonvoting member. Members must have a commitment to Latino culture and history, along with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, or teaching at the postsecondary level. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community requires members with expertise in Latino culture and history, museum administration, fundraising, or teaching at the postsecondary level. Additionally, experience in studying the issue of the Smithsonian Institution's representation of American Latino art, life, history, and culture, extensive experience in public or elected service, or experience in the administration or planning of museums focused on ethnic, racial, or cultural groups in American history is valued. The Commission's functions are outlined in Section 3. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will develop fundraising plans and examine issues related to collections and the impact of the Museum on the Hispanic community. The Commission will consider the availability and cost of collections, the impact on regional Hispanic museums, possible locations in Washington, DC, governance structure, community engagement, and legislation to establish the National Museum of the American Latino Community. The Commission will submit recommendations for a legislative plan to create the Museum to relevant House and Senate committees. Additionally, a national conference on the Museum will be convened within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of the Interior will provide necessary administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission. Members not federal employees may receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary. The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment and will terminate 30 days after submission. $2.1 million is authorized for fiscal year 2007 and $1.1 million for fiscal year 2008 for Commission activities.
